title: Zee Tai Chung Co
creator: Evert L. "Shorty" Fuller
description: A panoramic view of a main business district in Boise, Idaho. Businesses including Zee Tai Chung Co, selling Chinese goods, at 904 West Idaho. The building is the same as the Pacific Hotel run by George B. Smith. The background scene is dominated by a church under construction and civic buildings. From left to right you can see the First Baptist Church on Tenth and West Jefferson, the First Presbyterian Church on Ninth and State, the Columbia Theatre roof, the Boise Central School, and the Ada County Courthouse.
subject: Churches; Cities & towns; City & town life; Cityscapes; Cityscape photographs; Social & civic facilities; Stone buildings; Storefronts; Stores & shops; Streets; Architecture

title: Idaho World Newspaper, Idaho City, Idaho.jpg
creator: Richard Mouser
description:
Idaho City, Idaho (once known as Bannock or Boise City) is a town in Idaho that was once the largest city in the Pacific Northwest, larger than Portland and Seattle in 1863.
In the year 1863, two pioneers in Idaho City, Idaho, created a newspaper called Boise News. The company later changed the name of the newspaper to 'The Idaho World'. This was the first newspaper created in the territory of Idaho. This building was owned by various pioneers, and was a Chinese business named Man Wo Corner before Idaho World newspaper bought the building for their newspaper company.

title: Moore Gulch Chinese Mining Site 2 - Pierce Idaho.jpg
creator: Karl Roenke, United States Forest Service
description: The Moore Gulch Chinese Mining Site is an archaeological site dating from ca. 1870–1900 and is located in the Clearwater National Forest, Idaho, United States. It is listed on the US National Register of Historic Places. Original caption in source document: General site area of Chinese dump - looking east.

description: The Moore Gulch Chinese Mining Site is an archaeological site dating from ca. 1870–1900 and is located in the Clearwater National Forest, Idaho, United States. It is listed on the US National Register of Historic Places. Original caption in source document: Surface artifacts (including Chinese ceramics) found at site. title: View from China Mountain (15539408141).jpg
creator: U.S. Department of the Interior
description: Secretary of the Interior Sally Jewell joined Bureau of Land Management Deputy Director Steve Ellis, U.S. Senators Mike Crapo and James Risch, local stakeholders and ranchers to see first-hand efforts to conserve the sagebrush habitat that supports wildlife, outdoor recreation and other economic activity throughout the West.

title: Chinese parade, Go-Hing festival, May 1921 (MOHAI 5450).jpg
creator: Museum of History and Industry
description: In late May 1921, Seattle's Chinese community held a carnival, called Go-Hing, to raise money for famine relief in China. All of Seattle was invited to a week of Chinese music, dance, and food. The festival ended with a parade In this photo, Chinese lion dancers march along King Street in the parade that ended the Go-Hing festival. According to The Seattle Times, the lion's head was brought in from a Chinese group in Idaho especially for the festival.through downtown Seattle.
subject: Go-Hing (Event); Parades & processions; Community service; Famines Chinese Americans--Social life
location: Chinatown (Seattle, Wash." King Street (Seattle, Wash." Seattle (Wash.)
